titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Pennsylvania Commission for Women Records, 1979-1988 AIS.2006.10
titlestmt.author: Wendy Pflug

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-07-08 17:22:54 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: The Pennsylvania Commission for Women (PACW) was established in 1975 by Executive Order 1975-3 to insure that women had full and equal opportunities as citizens of the Commonwealth and to be a strong advocate for the rights of women in the state. Their records highlight efforts to eradicate sex discrimination, raise awareness and educate the public on issues concerning women in Pennsylvania.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: The Pennsylvania Commission for Women (PACW) was created by Executive Order 1975-3 and signed by Governor Milton J. Shapp on February 27, 1975. The Commission's objective was to develop and carry out policies "to help insure that women had full and equal opportunities as citizens of the Commonwealth and to increase State government's effort to eradicate sex discrimination against women in Pennsylvania." The Commission was also tasked with being a strong advocate for the rights of women, to raise awareness, and to educate the public on issues concerning women.

The PACW was comprised of "at least fifteen but not more than twenty-one members appointed by the Governor and shall function in an advisory capacity to the Director." Members served one or two year terms and served without salary. The commission director was appointed by the Governor and reported directly to him, advising on matters affecting women.

To raise awareness for and to educate the public on issues concerning women, the Commission would regularly give speeches to groups such as the League of Women Voters, local chambers of commerce, and college audiences in Pennsylvania. Members of the Commission also made media appearances and contributed opinion editorials to newspapers, prepared news releases and provided background information to the media. The Commission compiled complete research data on women by collecting statistics on women in the family, labor force, education, and other categories. The PACW published a quarterly newsletter Women's News, which provided information on legislation and other data and events of particular concern to women. They also published pamphlets and brochures on topics such as sexual harassment, day care options, and divorce. Each brochure and pamphlet advised women of their legal rights and provided a list of state services, programs, and agencies to assist them.

The Commission participated in and worked closely with associations and coalitions of women's groups throughout Pennsylvania and the Mid-Atlantic region. In this capacity, they provided information and training for local organizations in a statewide conference for local commissions for women.

The PACW also founded More Women Candidates, a non-partisan organization which developed educational programs to increase the number of women candidates for public office. In this capacity, the Commission also committed to a ten-year project from 1981 to 1991 in order to track the number of women in elected office. The project collected, reported, and publicized the number of women elected to public office at all levels of government.

The Pennsylvania Commission for Women continues its mission as an agent of change and empowerment for the Commonwealth's women. It has also expanded its scope and is an ardent advocate for health care, business, and human rights legislation concerning women. Governor Edward G. Rendell signed the most recent Executive Order to continue the PACW's work on June 22, 2003. Governor Rendell appointed twenty-six members to the Commission and named Leslie Stiles as Executive Director.
Cited: Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, Governor's Office, Executive Order 1975-3. Establishment of the Pennsylvania Commission for Women, February 27, 1975.

p.extref: Pennsylvania Commission for Women Web site

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Pennsylvania Commission for Women Records date from 1979 to 1988 and document the activities of the organization to help insure women had full and equal rights as citizens of Pennsylvania and to advocate for the rights of women in the Commonwealth. Most of the documents in this collection were created during the tenure of PACW Director, Christine Myers Crist (1983-1987). Included in the records are meeting minutes, budget information, activities reports, publications, and workshop materials that illustrate the ways the PACW sought to accomplish their objective.

odd.p: Pennsylvania Commission for Women Records, 1979-1988, AIS.2006.06, Archives Service Center, University of Pittsburgh

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Wendy Pflug in December 2009.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains documents relating to the administration of the Pennsylvania Commission for Women (PACW) from 1980 to 1988. The majority of these files are meeting minutes, agendas, notes, and related information. These meetings set the tone for goals the commission sought to achieve. Information on such issues as child care and credit equality can be found in the files related to meetings. Most meetings were held quarterly in Harrisburg, unless noted. Included in this series are bi-weekly activities reports, research files on various women's issues, and budget reports submitted to the legislature, which provide a detailed summary of activities, progress made, and goals achieved. The Administrative series also contains files from More Women Candidates, a non-partisan organization founded by the commission to create educational programs to increase the number of women candidates for public office. This series is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Education and Outreach series chronicles efforts to raise awareness and educate the public on various issues concerning women. The PACW was active in arranging programs, conferences, and workshops that dealt with a variety of issues relevant to women such as, re-entering the workforce, sexual discrimination and harassment, mental health, divorce, women in the workplace, and day care. Included in this series are files that were maintained by commission Director Christine Myers Crist on speaking engagements, and opinion-editorial pieces (Op-Eds) she wrote and newspaper clippings that cite PACW and the topics they worked to address. The material in the Education and Outreach series dates from 1980 to 1987 and is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Commission Publications series dates from 1979 to 1987 and is arranged chronologically by publication title. This series contains the Women's News, a statewide quarterly publication created by the PACW with information on topics that affected opportunities for women. The commission also created brochures and pamphlets detailing state services and programs available to women.
